Files

This lab description is available as a PDF file here. The code distribution may be downloaded (in zip format) here, or by running athrun 6.01 getFiles from an Athena machine or a 6.01 lab laptop.

Goals: To gain a deeper understanding of probabilistic state estimation by experimenting with a random process and a state estimator.

1) Getting Started

Do this lab on your own or with a partner of your choosing. You will need a laptop that reliably runs lib601.

Get today's files by running 

> athrun 6.01 getFiles

If you are not using a lab laptop, make sure you are using version S14-5 of lib601, and redownload if necessary. You can tell which version you have by opening CMax looking at the title bar.
NOTE: All multiple choice questions on this page only allow 1 submission. Try your best, and make sure you understand the answer. These questions will not affect your grade, but will be discussed in the checkoff.

2) Introduction

This week, we are going to be examining the problem of Bayesian state estimation: trying to determine the state S of a time-varying system, when we cannot directly observe that state. Although we cannot directly observe the state, we are able to make observations O about the system, which are dependent on S.

Our ultimate goal is to infer the actual internal state of the system. We will do this by maintaining a belief state, which is a distribution P(St) over states that the system might be in at time t. We will model the underlying system as a hidden Markov model, which has three critical components, all of which we know:

  • An initial distribution P(S0) : a probability distribution over the states of the system that determines the starting state of the system

  • A transition distribution P(St+1 | St) : a distribution over possible states at time t+1 , given the state of the system at time t

  • An observation distribution P(Ot | St) : a distribution over possible observations, given the state of the system

At the beginning of any given time step t , we already have a "prior" belief P(St) . On each step, we will update our belief as follows:

  • Make an observation o , and use this to generate an updated belief P(S′t | Ot=o) .

  • Generate an updated belief after a transition, P(St+1) . This result will serve as our prior on the next time step.

Check Yourself 1:

Notice that we don't have access to P(S | O), but we need to determine it after making an observation. How can we use what we do know to figure out P(S | O)?

3) Hallway World

In this week's tutor exercises, we will develop a Bayesian state estimator in Python. The goal of today's lab is to try to develop an intuition for how a belief distribution evolves over time in such a system. As such, we will make use of the state estimator in lib601.1

As an example, we will work in the context of an abstract simulation of a robot moving up and down a finite one-dimensional hallway. The robot can move forward and backward, but it never rotates. Thus the x coordinate of its location can change, but the y coordinate does not change. We discretize the robot's x position, and represent it as an integer value between 0 and a constant numStates - 1, inclusive. This integer will be the state of our system.

  • The robot starts out knowing how many states there are, but not knowing what state it is in.

  • The robot will observe a discretized sonar value, in the range 0 to 9, representing the distance to the left wall (which depends on the state). The robot knows, for each state, what an ideal distance sensor would read and uses that to determine a probability distribution over what discrete observations it would make if it were in that state.

  • The robot can only move forward; if it tries to move past the end of the hallway, it will stay in the forward-most location.

In this first example, we will put the robot in a world with 9 states. The ideal (discretized) sonar readings in states 0 through 8 are 1, 8, 8, 1, 1, 8, 1, 8, and 8, respectively, for this world. In code, this world is simply represented as: 

 
ideal = [1,8,8,1,1,8,1,8,8]

3.1) An abbreviated hallway

Consider an abbreviated version of this problem, in which the world consists only of the four leftmost states. Imagine the robot starts out thinking it is most likely in the rightmost (forward-most) state, but it isn't sure. So, its initial belief b0 is:
Pr(S = 0)
Pr(S = 1)
Pr(S = 2)
Pr(S = 3)
0.1 0.1 0.1 0.7

If its observation model is 

def obsGivenLoc(loc):
    if loc == 0 or loc == 3:
        return DDist({1: .8, 8 : .2})
    else:
        return DDist({1: .2, 8 : .8})

3.2) Simulator

We have provided you with a simulator to help you build intuition about how the world works and what the state estimation process is doing.

You can invoke it by running the following from a terminal window: 

> cd ~/Desktop/6.01_S14/swLab12
> python swLab12.py
or by opening swLab12.py in Idle2 and running it.

Doing so will create a simulation window:

Near the top of this window, you will see a display of the world, with a white box for each state, and a red dot (representing the robot) in one box. Below each box, you see a number representing the ideal reading the robot would see if it were in that state and had a perfect sensor. This "world" diagram represents some actual underlying process, about which we are making our predictions.

At the bottom of the window, you will see two buttons. Pressing the "Transition" button will cause both the underlying system and the state estimator to update. Pressing the "Reset" button will cause both the underlying system to return to a new state drawn from the initial distribution and the state estimator to return to its initial belief state.

After making your first transition, you will see text just below the world model that tells what sensor reading was observed.

Finally, you see (again, after making your first transition) four graphs, and associated numerical values:

  • The first, in green, are the individual probabilities of making the observation we made, for each of the states: P(O|S).

  • The second is the prior belief, before updating based on the observation or the action: P(St).

  • The third is the belief after updating based on the observation only: P(S′t | Ot=o) .

  • The final graph is the belief after updating based on both the transition and the observation, P(St+1). The next time the system is stepped, this distribution will show up as the prior.

The simulator is created by calling the simulate function in swLab12.py. Notice that, as the code is written, the simulator is called with an observation model which always returns the ideal value, and a transition model in which the robot moves exactly one state forward (to the right) on each timestep.

If you change this call to simulate (including changing the models), you will need to close the currently-open simulator window and run the commands above to re-open the simulator.

Check Yourself 2:

Run a few steps of the simulator, and make sure the visualization makes sense. If it doesn't, ask a staff member for help.

Checkoff 1:

Discuss the following with a staff member:

  • What is the difference between a state and an observation?
  • Explain the ideal list.
  • What does mixture do, and what is the parameter p?
  • What is an observation model, and how is it used in state estimation?
  • Explain the graphs in the simulator window.

Checkoffs are handled through the 6.01 Help Queue.

4) Observation models

An observation model is a conditional probability distribution, Pr(Ot | St) . Given a state, it tells us how likely a given observation would be if the robot were in that state.

Consider two observation models, which we will refer to as observation model A and observation model B:

  • Observation model A describes a sensor that returns the ideal value with probability 0.7, and returns 0 with probability 0.3.
  • Observation model B describes a sensor that returns the ideal value with probability 0.7, and, with probability 0.3, returns a random integer in the range [0,9] (including the endpoints of the range and distributed uniformly).

Observation Model A is defined for you in swLab12.py. Implement obsModelB in swLab12.py; we will expect to see the simulator running with this model during checkoff.

1
2
def obsModelB(state):
    return dist.mixture(dist.deltaDist(ideal[state]),dist.uniformDist(range(0, 10)),0.7)

4.1) Polonius and Ralph

  • Polonius Python makes a bad design decision in his sensor circuit, so that when the ideal discrete sonar reading is x, his sensor reads 9−x. It is entirely reliable (there is no noise). Luckily, Polonius realizes this, and constructs an observation model (obsModelC) for the state estimator that reflects the design error.
  • Ralph Reticulatus makes a terrible implementation mistake in his sensor circuit, leaving values floating, so that when the ideal discrete sonar reading is x, the sensor reads x with probability 0.5, and 9−x with probability 0.5. Ralph realizes this and constructs an observation model (obsModelD) for the state estimator that reflects the implementation error.

Both of these observation models have been implemented for you in swLab12.py.

Compare models C and D by answering these true/false questions. We will say that two models behave equivalently if, for all possible sequences of observations, the two models result in the same posterior belief distribution.

  • Polonius's physical sensor used with observation model C behaves equivalently to a perfect sensor with a perfect sensor model.
    100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
  • In an environment with only ideal readings 1 and 8, Ralph's physical sensor used with observation model D behaves equivalently to a perfect sensor with a perfect sensor model.
    100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
  • Polonius's physical sensor used with observation model C behaves equivalently to a broken sensor that always returns 0 and a sensor model that assigns probability 1 to getting observation 0.
    100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
  • In an environment with only ideal readings 1 and 8, Ralph's physical sensor used with observation model D behaves equivalently to a broken sensor that always returns 0 and a sensor model that assigns probability 1 to getting observation 0.
    100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
  • In an environment with ideal readings 1 and 2, Ralph's physical sensor used with observation model D behaves equivalently to a broken sensor that always returns 0 and a sensor model that assigns probability 1 to getting observation 0.
    100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
  • In an environment with ideal readings 1 and 2, Ralph's physical sensor used with observation model D behaves equivalently to Polonius's sensor and observation model C.
    100.00%

5) Transition Models

In this section, we will consider a hallway that is numStates locations long, where all of the walls are the same distance away, so the observations are uninformative.

A transition model is a conditional probability distribution, Pr(St+1|St) . Given a state, it tells us into which states the robot is likely to transition.

Consider the following transition models:

  • Teleport Model: The robot moves 1 state forward (to the right) with probability 0.7, and teleports to a random state (distributed uniformly) with probability 0.3.
  • Teleport Model 2: The robot remains in its current state with probability 0.7, and teleports to a random state (distributed uniformly) with probability 0.3.
  • Reset Model: The robot moves 1 state forward (to the right) with probability 0.7, and moves to state 0 with probability 0.3.
  • Reset Model 2: The robot remains in its current state with probability 0.7, and moves to state 0 with probability 0.3.

All of these except resetModel have been implemented for you. Implement resetModel in swLab12.py.

1
2
3
4
5
def resetModel(state):
    a = moveRightModel(state)
    b = dist.deltaDist(0)
    return dist.mixture(a, b, 0.7)
